publication.abstract: Motivation: Pairwise relatedness plays an important role in a range of genetic research fields. However, currently only few estimators exist for individuals that are admixed, i.e. have ancestry from more than one population, and these estimators fail in some situations.Results: We present a new software tool, RelateAdmix, for obtaining maximum likelihood estimates of pairwise relatedness from genetic data between admixed individuals. We show using simulated data that it gives rise to better estimates than three state-of-the-art software tools, REAP, KING and Plink, while still being fast enough to be applicable to large datasets. publication.title: RelateAdmix: A software tool for estimating relatedness between admixed individuals

summary.description: This is a method which estimates the probability of sharing alleles identity by descent (IBD) across the genome and can also be used for mapping disease loci using distantly related individuals.
